questions.question: Question 1: Which family does yellow fever virus belong to?
questions.explanation:
Yellow fever virus belongs to the family flaviviridae, which contains the genus Flavivirus. The important species under genus Flavivirus include: • Yellow fever virus • Dengue virus • Japanese encephalitis virus • Kyasanur forest disease virus • West Nile encephalitis • Zikavirus Note: Arbovirus is a term used to refer to any viruses that are transmitted by arthropod vectors. 
There is no family or order by the name arbovirus. The word arbovirus stands 
for ARthropod-BOrne virus.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 10-year-old boy from Uttar Pradesh was rushed to the emergency department with a 
headache, fever, and blurred vision followed shortly by unresponsiveness to verbal 
commands. He is suspected to have viral encephalitis. Which of the following transmits this 
endemic disease?
questions.explanation:
Endemic viral encephalitis is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis. It is transmitted 
by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnuii. It is the leading cause of childhood neurological viral infection in India. In endemic areas such as 
North India, it typically affects children <15 years of age as by early adulthood, the majority of 
the population has protective immunity following natural exposure to the virus. Ardeid birds like herons and egrets are reservoir hosts, while the amplifier hosts are pigs. It is 
transmitted by Culex mosquitoes, and human infection is a tangential dead end.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis?

options.d: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.explanation:
Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus. 425 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in 
India) species. Option B: Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts. Option D: The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the 
human dwellings and vaccinating pigs. The image below shows the life cycle of the Japanese B encephalitis virus.

questions.question:
Question 4: A mother brings her 9-month-old child for vaccination against Japanese encephalitis. Which 
of the following statements is false regarding this vaccine? 416 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Two doses are recommended at age 9 months and 18 months
options.b: Inactivated vero cell culture is given 4 weeks apart
options.c: Live vaccine SA 14-14-2 is administered intramuscularly
options.d: The live attenuated vaccine can be given to adolescents

questions.explanation:
Live SA 14-14-2 strain of Japanese encephalitis (JE) vaccine is administered subcutaneously. Types of JE Vaccines: Inactivated vero cell culture

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient presents with fever, arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. On 
examination, she has the following rash. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. 
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with the symptoms and the rash suggests dengue fever. It presents with sudden-onset fever, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The rash in 
dengue appears as white islands on a red sea due to erythema with petechiae. The alternative 
name for dengue, breakbone fever, comes from the associated muscle and joint pains. Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies. The treatment of dengue is supportive with hydration taking top priority.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 35-year-old wildlife photographer presents with sudden onset of fever, headache, and 
myalgia. On examination, you notice gingival bleeds and conjunctival hemorrhages. He 
recently visited a forest in Karnataka that has a large population of monkeys. Which of these 
is the vector for the suspected disease?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario with exposure to monkeys, fever, myalgia, headache, conjunctival 
hemorrhage and gingival bleeds is suggestive of Kyasanur forest disease (KFD), which is 
transmitted by ticks (Haemophysalis spinigera). It is endemic to the forests 
of Karnataka and Kerala. The clinical features include: • Fever • Headache • Conjunctivitis • Myalgia • Meningoencephalitis • Hemorrhagic symptoms- hemorrhages in skin, mucosa and gastrointestinal bleeds. The case fatality rate is about 5 percent. Monkeys are amplifier hosts, rodents are reservoirs and humans are incidental hosts. A killed KFD virus vaccine was used in a small field trial and appeared to provide some degree of 
protection.

questions.question:
Question 7: A middle-aged man presents with delirium, fever, jaundice, and a hemorrhagic diathesis. The 
patient is agitated and has had no urine output in the last 6 hours. On investigation, there is 
azotemia and elevated liver enzymes. A viral disease with the vector shown below is 
suspected. Which of the following inclusion bodies may be seen?
questions.explanation:
The image shows the Aedes aegypti mosquito and the clinical scenario with hepatic and renal 
dysfunction with delirium points towards a diagnosis of yellow fever. Torres bodies are 
amorphous eosinophilic nuclear inclusions associated with yellow fever, a disease caused by the 
Flavivirus. Inclusion bodies are structures with distinct sizes and shapes that are seen in virus-infected cells 
under light microscopy. Note: Dengue hemorrhagic fever can be a differential diagnosis, but there are no inclusion bodies 
seen in dengue. 427 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: What is the duration of validity of 17D vaccination?
questions.explanation:
17D vaccine (yellow fever vaccine) is valid for a lifetime, beginning 10 days after 
vaccination. According to the amendment in 2016 to International Health Regulations 2005, the 
validity of the related international certificate of vaccination against yellow fever has been 
changed from ten (10) years to the lifespan of the person (traveler) vaccinated. It is a live-attenuated vaccine derived from the 'Asibi strain', administered 
subcutaneously. Immunity after a single dose is long-lasting and provides lifetime protection. It is 
thermolabile. Vaccination is compulsory for travel to and from endemic areas. In India, 17D is manufactured at the Central Research Institute, Kasauli.

questions.question:
Question 9: A pest control technician with a history of fever, vomiting, hematuria, and decreased urine 
output was diagnosed with hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome. Which of the following 
statements is false about the causative virus?

options.a: Hantaviruses are the natural pathogens of rodents
options.b: Transmission primarily occurs by Culex mosquitoes
options.c: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome presents with pulmonary edema

questions.explanation:
Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) is caused by Hantaviruses. They are rodent-borne 
viruses that are transmitted by inhalation of the virus contained in dried excreta of rodents. They 
are the natural pathogens of rodents like mice, rats, and voles. HFRS presents with acute kidney injury, hemorrhages, fever, and circulatory 
collapse. Hantaviruses can also cause Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. Note: In Aug 2016, The International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV), has renamed 
and moved the genus Hantavirus to Orthohantavirus.

questions.question:
Question 10: An epidemic of paralytic poliomyelitis occurs in a non-immune population. Which among the 
following strains of poliovirus is the most common cause of this?
questions.explanation:
Type 1 poliovirus is the most common cause of epidemics in populations. Poliovirus strains have been classified into 3 types: • Type 1- most common and causes most of the epidemics. • Type 2- endemic infections. • Type 3- epidemics but rarer than type 1. Immunity is type-specific. Note :- Type 2 is declared eradicated in September, 2015 and Type 3 is declared eradicated in 
October, 2019

questions.question:
Question 11: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrics OPD with a history of lower-limb paralysis and 
the following deformity. Which of the following will be the most common form of 
presentation of this illness? 419 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
428 
Sold by @itachibot The given case scenario with a history of lower limb paralysis and deformity is suggestive of 
poliomyelitis. The given image shows deformity of the right lower limb, namely hyperextension at 
the knee joint and muscle wasting. Inapparent infection is the most common (90-95%) presentation of polio. Only seroconversion 
occurs without any clinical manifestations. Option B: Abortive poliomyelitis is associated with primary viremia and presents as fever, 
headache, sore throat, and malaise lasting for 1-5 days. Option C: Paralytic poliomyelitis occurs following minor illness, characterized by biphasic fever 
with headache, stiff neck, and flaccid paralysis. Option D: In non-paralytic poliomyelitis, the disease does not progress beyond the stage of aseptic 
meningitis.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 20-year-old unimmunized patient presents to you with complaints of weakness of lower 
limbs, inability to pass urine, and fever, for 3 days. His stool samples were sent to the district 
lab to confirm the diagnosis. Which region of the spinal cord will primarily be affected in 
these cases?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario of fever, lower limb paralysis, urinary retention, and stool samples being 
sent for diagnosis, is suggestive of paralytic polio. The anterior horn cells of the spinal cord are 
primarily affected, causing acute flaccid paralysis. Posterior horns and intermediate 
columns/lateral horns may also be involved to some extent. In the central nervous system, the virus multiplies selectively in the neurons and destroys them. 
The earliest change is the degeneration of Nissl bodies (chromatolysis). Nuclear changes follow. Note: Fecal samples of all cases of acute flaccid paralysis are obtained (2 samples) and 
transported to the laboratory within 72 hours of collection at 4–8°C or frozen at -20°C. This is 
known as the reverse cold chain and is done as a part of gold standard polio surveillance/acute 
flaccid paralysis surveillance (AFP surveillance).

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following statements is false regarding vaccination against polio?

options.a: Sabin type has the live attenuated virus
options.b: OPV should not be administered to immunocompromised persons
options.c: Salk vaccine is associated with mutations that lead to reversal of virulence
options.d: Both OPV and IPV induce humoral Ig™

questions.explanation:
Salk type is the killed vaccine, hence there is no risk of mutation that can lead to a reversal of 
virulence. There are two types of vaccines for polio - IPV (inactivated poliovirus vaccine) and OPV (oral 
poliovirus vaccine).

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following strains of poliovirus have been eradicated worldwide?
questions.explanation:
Type 2 and 3 have been eradicated worldwide. Type 2: In September 2015, WHO declared the eradication of the wild type 2 poliovirus strain. In 
India, the last type 2 infection was detected in 1999. Type 3: It has not been detected anywhere in the world since November 2012. On World Polio 
Day in October 2019, the type 3 virus was declared to be eradicated worldwide. 429 
Sold by @itachibot The only circulating strain is type 1.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 68-year-old woman presented with acute chest pain which was stabbing type in nature. The 
pain is spasmodic and associated with fever spikes. There's an outbreak of coxsackievirus B in 
her community. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario with stabbing type chest pain which is spasmodic in nature, associated 
with fever spikes, and history of an outbreak of coxsackievirus B is suggestive of Bornholm disease 
or epidemic pleurodynia. Symptoms include paroxysms of acute pleuritic chest pain associated with fever spikes. Involved 
muscles are tender. Chest X-ray is usually normal. Most cases occur during epidemics 
of coxsackievirus B. The disease is named after the Danish island of Bornholm where early cases 
occurred. The treatment is non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents or hot fomentation of the involved 
muscles. Other diseases associated with coxsackievirus B: • Neonatal myocarditis and pericarditis • Juvenile diabetes mellitus • Orchitis • Severe disseminated congenital infection- hepatitis, meningoencephalitis, adrenocortical 
involvement

questions.question:
Question 16: A 5-year-old boy presents with headache, fever, and vomiting. On examination, you observe 
the following. He is diagnosed with herpangina. Which group of viruses causes the same? 421 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows palatal ulcers in herpangina. It is caused by the coxsackievirus A, a large 
subgroup of the enteroviruses. Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is characterized by grayish- white papulovesicular lesions on 
an erythematous base that ulcerate. These are present on: • Soft palate • Anterior pillars of tonsils • Uvula • Posterior oropharynx It is a common clinical manifestation of coxsackievirus A infection in children, but it can also be 
caused by coxsackievirus B, echoviruses, or enterovirus 71. Treatment is usually only supportive, as the disease is self-limiting and usually runs its course in 
less than a week.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following organisms causes the following disease?
questions.explanation:
430 
Sold by @itachibot The image shows vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, consistent with 
hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is caused by coxsackievirus. Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young 
children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and 
soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically 
differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. It is usually a benign illness 
resolving in 1-2 weeks. Coxsackie A16, A9, and B 1-3 are common causative agents. Other diseases caused by Coxsackie A virus: • Aseptic meningitis associated with a maculopapular rash. • Herpangina • Minor respiratory infections

questions.question:
Question 18: A 60-year-old presented with eye pain, watering of eyes, and increased sensitivity to light. On 
examination, you see the following. Which of the following viruses can cause this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (AHC) caused mainly by 
Enterovirus 70 and Coxsackievirus A24 variant (CA24v). It is characterized by sudden swelling, congestion, and watering of the eyes. Subconjunctival 
hemorrhages are a characteristic feature and corneal involvement may occur transiently. There is no treatment currently available. The disease is self limiting, and resolves within a five to 
seven-day period. Note: Acute follicular conjunctivitis is caused by Adenovirus serotypes 3, 4, 7 and 11.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 42-year-old woman presented with fever, joint pains, and headache. Chik sign (image given 
below) is present on the patient's nose. Which of the following vectors transmits the 
etiological agent? 423 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario with fever, joint pain, headache, and Chik sign is suggestive of 
chikungunya which is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. Chikungunya presents with sudden onset of fever, crippling joint pain, lymphadenopathy, and 
conjunctivitis. The fever is typically biphasic with a period of remission after 1–6 days. Nose 
pigmentation is striking in cases of Chikungunya fever and is termed as Chik sign No animal reservoir has been identified. Note: Although Chikungunya is transmitted by both Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, 
A.Aegypti is considered primary vector of transmission for Chikungunya. 431 
Sold by @itachibot Miscellaneous Viruses - Rubella, Coronaviruses, 
Prions, Rotavirus, Filovirus, Zika Virus and Nipah Virus
